questions.question: Which one of the following is NOT a method used for logging messages in a server-side script for a privately-scoped application?
answers: A. gs.log()
B. gs.error()
C. gs.warn()
D. gs.debug()

comments.content:
Scoped Application Script Logging

gs.print() and gs.log() are older and not available in scoped applications, whereas gs.debug(), gs.info(), gs.warn(), gs.error() work in both scoped applications and global are therefore are more versatile going forward in future versions.

Keep in mind that, info, error, warn and debug logging methods are not only intended for Scoped Applications but can also be used in the Global Scope. However, these logging methods provide verbosity levels to a log message. Another consideration is that gs.log() cannot be used if you are developing in a scoped application.
gs.log is not used in scoped applications

gs.print() and gs.log() are older and not available in scoped applications, whereas gs.debug(), gs.info(), gs.warn(), gs.error() work in both scoped applications and global are therefore are more versatile going forward in future versions.

Reference: https://developer.servicenow.com/dev.do#!/guides/utah/now-platform/tpb-guide/debugging_best_practices

questions.question: How must Application Access be configured to prevent all other private application scopes from creating configuration records on an application's data tables?
answers: A. You must create Access Controls to prevent all other application scopes from creating configuration records on an application's data tables rather than using Application Access
B. Set the Accessible from field value to All application scopes and de-select the Can create option
C. Set the Accessible from field value to This application scope only and de-select the Allow access to this table via web services option
D. Set the Accessible from field value to This application scope only

comments.content: Correct answer is D. When Accessible from is set to "This app scope only", then "Allow configuration" is unchecked and read-only
Accessible and create are not same. The question here is about creation and not to block access on the records.
The question specifically talks about creating, not completely blocking.
Correct is B. We only want to disable create

The question is about preventing to file creation so other activities should be allowed. Hence B is correct.
Answer D disallows all other activities.
The most correct answer is B.

Just tested this in a Vancouver PDI.
When selecting "This application scope only", all the check boxes are cleared and become read-only.
To prevent all other app scopes, simply select “This application scope only”.
D is the best option. B is also correct in a way but since one option only, can select D

Correct answer is D.
Check the following 2 examples of denying and granting access.
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/tokyo-application-development/page/build/applications/concept/c_ExampleDenyingAllRuntimeAccess.html

https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/tokyo-application-development/page/build/applications/concept/c_ExampleGrantingAllRuntimeAccess.html

I would say both B and D could be correct, however, D would also disable the read/update/delete, not just the create function. The question isn't clear whether the table should still be readable by others or not.

I agree with D refer  to
https://developer.servicenow.com/dev.do#!/learn/learning-plans/rome/new_to_servicenow/app_store_learnv2_securingapps_rome_application_access

D - Reference
Note: If you set Accessible From to This Application Scope Only, it automatically unchecks and greys out Web Services so it can't be C

https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/rome-application-development/page/build/applications/concept/c_ExampleDenyingAllDesignAccess.html

answers: A. Insert, Delete, Query, Write
B. Create, Delete, Read, Write
C. Create, Delete, Read, Update
D. Insert, Delete, Query, Update

comments.content: The question is about table not the business rule, so the correct answer is C

check your PDI
Only valid choices for ACL type (from this question) are Read, Write, Delete, Create

[Your PDI].service-now.com/sys_security_operation_list.do?sysparm_query=&sysparm_first_row=1&sysparm_view=

Answer: C
Please replicate yourself before deciding which is the correct answer. Question states when creating a table within a privately scoped application. 
1. Navigate to studio and create an application. 
2. Create Application File - Select Table - Create
3. Navigate to Application Access - Related Tab
4. You can see check boxes: Can Read, Can Create, Can Update, Can Delete

This is not a BD operation and its access controls.

the answer is B as stated in the developer page for access controls
https://developer.servicenow.com/dev.do#!/learn/learning-plans/utah/new_to_servicenow/app_store_learnv2_securingapps_utah_securing_table_records

Correct answer is B
Access Controls are automatically created when tables are added to scoped applications. The four default Access Controls grant access to the table's records. Permission is granted for these operations:

Create
Read
Write
Delete

https://developer.servicenow.com/dev.do#!/learn/learning-plans/tokyo/new_to_servicenow/app_store_learnv2_securingapps_tokyo_securing_table_records

When creating a table in a privately-scoped application in ServiceNow, the system automatically generates four Access Control Lists (ACLs) for the table to provide basic access control. These ACLs control the following CRUD operations:

    Create: This ACL controls the ability to create new records in the table. It ensures that only users with the appropriate roles or permissions can add new records to the table.

    Read: This ACL controls the ability to view or read records in the table. It ensures that only users with the appropriate roles or permissions can access the data stored in the table.

    Update: This ACL controls the ability to modify or update records in the table. It ensures that only users with the appropriate roles or permissions can make changes to the data stored in the table.

    Delete: This ACL controls the ability to delete records in the table. It ensures that only users with the appropriate roles or permissions can remove records from the table.
C is correct. Can read, Can create, Can Update , Can Delete are the options
replies: I was wrong . B is correct
why indeed can read, create, update and delete are the options why is this wrong?

comments.content: create, delete, read, write is the options in Studio

questions.question: Which of the following statements must evaluate to true for a user to pass an Access Control? (Choose three.)
answers: A. The user has one of the roles specified in the Required roles related list.
B. Scripts configured in the Access Control must evaluate to true.
C. Other matching Access Controls for the records evaluate to true.
D. Conditions configured in the Access Control must evaluate to true.
E. The user must be granted access through a business rule.

comments.content:
I believe that the correct answer should be A, B, C and D

Source: https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/utah-platform-security/page/administer/contextual-security/concept/access-control-rules.html

Search for "ACL evaluation process" on the page and you can find the following line as well:
"[Record ACL rules only] The matching table-level and field-level ACL rules must both evaluate to true."
A :The user has one of the roles specified in the Required roles related list. true

questions.question: When debugging Email Notifications, what must you check on a user record? (Choose three.)
answers: A. Active must be true.
B. The First name and Last name fields must have values.
C. The value in the Notification field must be set to enabled.
D. The user must not be locked out.
E. The Email field must have a value.

comments.content: Must have email, must have notification enabled and should be active
Locked out users cannot receive emails

Check PDA. 
Notification field needs to be enabled
Active true
Email filled
There is no Notification field on the user record.
the notification field on sys_user seems to be mysterious...

**A. Active must be true.**  
  The user must have an active status to receive notifications.

- **D. The user must not be locked out.**  
  Locked-out users will not receive email notifications.

- **E. The Email field must have a value.**  
  The system requires a valid email address to send notifications.

### Why Not the Other Options?  
- **B. The First name and Last name fields must have values.**  
  These fields are not required for email notifications to function. While useful for personalization, their absence does not block notifications.

- **C. The value in the Notification field must be set to enabled.**  
  There is no specific "Notification" field on a user record. Notifications are enabled or disabled at the notification or system level, not per user through such a field.

A don't agree with "A". Active must be true? Active what? I know SN troubleshooting article lists a use case where if Incident is no longer active, the email is not sent out because Incident Opened email notification has a condition of [active] [is] [true]. But that is a single case, and hardly can be applied to troubleshooting all email notifications.

C - because notifications must be enabled
D - because locked users cannot receive emails by design: https://support.servicenow.com/kb?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0859406
E - because user will not get email if their email field is empty
replies:
Questing reads "what must be done on the user table", so correct answer must be ACDE
A-user is active
C-notification set to 'enabled'
D-user is not locked out
E-user email field is not empty

comments.content: Even if Notification field is set to false, users will still receive mandatory notifications.
C is mentioned in the book

"Restricted caller access [sys_restricted_caller_access] records track cross-scope applications or scripts that request access to an application, application resource, or event in the Now Platform." <<== this is the third sentence down in the following link:
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/tokyo-application-development/page/build/applications/concept/restricted-caller-access-privilege.html
A.  Restricted caller access [sys_restricted_caller_access] records track cross-scope applications or scripts that request access to an application, application resource, or event in the platform.

questions.question: Which ATF Test step allows you to create a user with speeded roles and groups for the test?
answers: A. Create a group
B. Impersonation
C. Create a user
D. Create a role

comments.content: "To impersonate a user, use the Create a User test step to create a user with specified roles and groups for the test. The user record gets rolled back after the test completes."

questions.question: What plugin enables the Guided Application Creator?
answers: A. com.glide.sn-guided-app-creator
B. com.glide.service_creator
C. com.glide.snc.apps_creator
D. com.snc.apps_creator_template

comments.content:
"Guided Application Creator is enabled via the Guided Application Creator (com.glide.sn-guided-app-creator) plugin, which is active by default in the Now Platform."
Located under "Activation Information" section at this URL:
https://docs.servicenow.com/en-US/bundle/tokyo-application-development/page/build/guided-app-creator/concept/guided-app-creator.html
